graft.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a piece of healthy skin or bone taken from someone’s body and put in or on another part of their body that has been damaged
graft.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Martha had to have several skin grafts.
graft.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a piece cut from one plant and tied to or put inside a cut in another, so that it grows there
graft.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Our success has been due to sheer hard graft.
graft.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the practice of obtaining money or advantage by the dishonest use of influence or power
graft.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: He promised to end graft in public life.
graft.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to remove a piece of skin, bone etc from part of someone’s body and put it onto or into a part of their body that has been damaged
graft.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The technique involves grafting a very thin slice of bone onto the damaged knee.
graft.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to join a part of a plant or tree onto another plant or tree
graft.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to add something very different to something, so that it becomes part of it
graft.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: New elements are being grafted onto our traditional form of government.
It is a 17th-century farmhouse with some Victorian additions grafted on.
graft.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: He put his success down to stamina, resilience, and sheer hard graft.
graft.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: when money or advantage is obtained by using power or influence in a dishonest way
graft.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The whole system is full of corruption and graft.
